citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
Review of IACUC records at time of the inspection indicate on August 18, 2022, a research assistant failed to properly
secure a clip to a syringe containing a protocol approved agent. This resulted in a macaque, on protocol 20130047AR,
receiving the agent intravenously at an incorrect rate. The animal became unresponsive, and the veterinary staff was
notified immediately. Despite immediate response, treatment and 24 -hour care the macaque’s condition never improved
and it was euthanized. Failing to properly train personnel involved in animal activities may have a negative impact on
animal health and well-being. Personnel conducting procedures on the species being maintained or studied should be
appropriately qualified and trained in those procedures. Corrective action taken included retraining research personnel in
proper syringe pump use and a visual and physical check of the connection.
Corrected a time of the inspection.
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with facility employees.
Additional Inspectors:
ELIZABETH PANNILL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.31(d)(1)(viii)  Critical
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). 
Review of IACUC records at time of the inspection indicate on August 18, 2022, a research assistant failed to properly 
secure a clip to a syringe containing a protocol approved agent. This resulted in a macaque, on protocol 20130047AR, 
receiving the agent intravenously at an incorrect rate. The animal became unresponsive, and the veterinary staff was 
notified immediately.  Despite immediate response, treatment and 24 -hour care the macaque’s condition never improved 
and it was euthanized. Failing to properly train personnel involved in animal activities may have a negative impact on 
animal health and well-being.  Personnel conducting procedures on the species being maintained or studied should be 
appropriately qualified and trained in those procedures. Corrective action taken included retraining research personnel in 
proper syringe pump use and a visual and physical check of the connection.  
Corrected a time of the inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with facility employees. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
ELIZABETH PANNILL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
